Tyrone Graham
Tired of selling my soul for 30 shekels. Crawling back to my first love — if she’ll have me.
Apr 9

The feeling

I have shaken fists
with the ague of passion 
that sees red as appointed, 
I have lashed out blindly 
to destroy all but the red, 
the scope of the spectrum: 
mindless, possessed,
a cutting edge
sawing at the jugular vein.

I have run cold
with the fury of the north, 
stone-eyed and cold-blooded 
as some reptilian past,
hooked fingers around a throat 
playing with life and death
and yielding neither: 
motherless, born of rock.

Yes, winds have swept me,
sweep me still: winds and tides 
and phases of the buffeting moon 
have tossed me here and there, 
from belief to black despair:
ebbs and flows, sins and scents 
of commission and omission
and there pebbles picked or not: 
a leaf before the wind,
faulting its fall.

Yet I have seen other leaves 
go with and against the wind, 
have seen ears from behind 
framing unknowing heads:
I have seen faces close
in pain, my pain,
and twist in folly, my folly:
I have seen men eat,
like me, humbled by hunger, 
hustled by the binding rain: 
and these eyes have seen
and these senses felt
with theirs: all mine
now, in this mellow mood 
where sadness is all,
a backdrop to the world,
a source of riddling springs 
sending forth streams of love —

And if I could make it fast, 
anchor it against the swirl,
I could comfort the world 
between palm and fingertip, 
father of endless happiness: 
a kinder god, soft enough
to foster men’s melting core.
